comment.author: 7892196@N02
comment._content:
would the round building by the Cyclorama?

Iain

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
Yes iain stuart, thanks;  it was the Sydney Cyclorama (1889-1906) which "showed representations in oils of the Battle of Gettysburg".  That doesn't help narrow the date at all, unfortunately.

The enormous size view is great, but I can't see any tramway pylons on the small section of George Street between Railway Square and Harris Street, which implies it is before late 1899.

comment.author: 22616984@N07
comment._content: The Cyclorama it is! The facility was tendered for in Sept 1888. and liquidated July 1910 I can't find an image of it online? There is an an image of the Melbourne Cyclorama, which looks identical.

comment.author: 22616984@N07
comment._content: Location and heritage details Opened 18 March 1889 (perhaps?)

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Thanks ibsut; my research was based on this description of the Cyclorama when it was about to open in 1889 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/28338813?searchTerm=cycl... and its imminent closure in 1906 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/14782824?searchTerm=cycl... . A small and interesting slice of Sydney's history, but a bit of a red herring when dating this photo (please excuse the mixed metaphor!).

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: The big white building in the middle looks shiny and new. Was it part of the Tooths Kent Brewery (KB). I have found out more than I want to know about C19th breweries but no luck, except that it does not seem to be marked on this 1895 map (nor does the Cyclorama), which might imply the photo is post 1895? 1895 interactive map - www.nla.gov.au/apps/cdview?pi=nla.map-rm3443-sd&rgn=0...

comment.author: 22616984@N07
comment._content: It would appear the Cyclorama was demolised by November 1906

comment.author: 63385174@N06
comment._content: The long sheds infront of the the Exhibition Building at Prince Alfred Park are the platform sheds of "Redfern" Station (as the old Central Station was known) which sat just south of the current Central Station platforms. There is no sign of the new (current) Central Station building so I would say the picture is late 1890's.

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/63385174@N06] Thanks for the info. Your guesstimate fits squarely into the date range 1892-July 1901.

AB

comment.author: 92723869@N07
comment._content: Beachcomber, I would suggest that what you have marked as Macquarie Lighthouse, seeing that it begins below the high point of the background, and given the difference of angle from the avenue in front of our Sydney University viewpoint, it is most likely to be the spire of St Mark's, Darling Point, which was erected in 1875.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/92723869@N07] juantoo34 - Thank you,  a slip of the mouse!  Now corrected.  Please do the honours with St Marks spire.  Or is it St Johns Darlinghurst?
